Award.AwardTitle: AF: SMALL: Provable Algorithms for Nonhermitian Matrices

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: Finding the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a matrix is among the most<br/>fundamental computational tasks. These quantities correspond to resonant<br/>frequencies and modes of physical, statistical, and mathematical systems and<br/>appear in essentially every area of science and engineering. First year<br/>college students are taught how to compute them on small examples, and two of<br/>the ``top 10 algorithms of the twentieth century'' --- the QR Algorithm and<br/>the Arnoldi algorithm --- were designed to do so on large instances. When the<br/>matrices involved are symmetric, these methods come with provable guarantees<br/>showing that they are accurate, fast, and correct. However, the general<br/>non-symmetric case remains poorly understood, and rigorously analyzing these<br/>algorithms in general has been a decades-old mystery in numerical analysis,<br/>despite their being implemented in standard software packages. The main goal<br/>of this project is to solve these and related mysteries using modern tools of<br/>random-matrix theory and theoretical computer science. Doing so will put a<br/>large branch of computational practice on solid theoretical footing, and<br/>ideally foster deeper interaction between the numerical analysis, mathematics,<br/>and theoretical computer science research communities.<br/><br/>Specifically, the project will aim to analyze the two (currently heuristic)<br/>algorithms mentioned above, with the following concrete major goals: (1) find<br/>a shifting strategy for the shifted QR method which provably converges rapidly<br/>for every matrix; (2) formalize a widely held belief precisely relating the<br/>output of the Arnoldi algorithm to the pseudospectrum of the input matrix.<br/>Secondarily, the award will study the adjacent problem of efficiently<br/>computing an approximation of the Jordan normal form of a given rational<br/>matrix in the variable precision model of computation, for which good<br/>complexity bounds are not known. The project will likely use techniques from<br/>random-matrix theory, dynamical systems, algebra, and numerical analysis,<br/>building on recent progress of the investigator and collaborators in some of<br/>these areas.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
